Key Arguments: The Bill grants excessive discretionary power to the government to define 'misinformation' and 'disinformation', which could be misused by future governments.
The Bill lacks adequate protections against misuse and does not sufficiently define 'serious harm'.
The legislation could lead to censorship of individual speech on digital platforms, contrary to claims that it targets industry standards.
The Bill deviates from international standards on freedom of speech as outlined in the ICCPR.
The suppression of dissenting views could impede scientific progress and democratic debate.
Notable Quotes: This Bill presents a Pandora’s Box of problems in its endeavour to regulate information disseminated on media platforms.
This Bill represents a serious departure from the international standard on freedom of speech.
Censoring online information will only increase dissenters’ suspicion towards government rather than enhance social cohesion.
